In any plan for one or more noncommercial educational television stations

atioru Furthermore, any proposal for educational television in Minnesota

The proposal has been made that the University of Minnesota serve as

A. BASIC LEGAL REQUIREICHTS FOR THE LICENSEE
Every broadcasting station roust have a licensee who thereby assumes certain
responsibilities before the law*
(1) All stations roust be operated in accordance with the provisions
of the Comunications Act of 193U and the Federal Communications Commission^
Rules. Among other things these require that the licensee be ultimately
responsible to the Commission for the station1s program, output and technical
operation. This responsibility cannot be shifted to anyone else; the
licensee therefore must be prepared to undergo any penalties assessed
against him by either the FCC or the Federal Courts as a result of violations
of the Camraunications Act or the FCC rules.
(2) The Commission®s Rules also provide that the licensee of a non¬
commercial educational television station be prepared to serve the gener al
educational television needs of its entire areas in other words, such
licensee could not operate solely with reference to its own immediate
interests. Among other things it must make sir time available to other
educational groups and agencies.
(3) Many legs! responsibilities stemming from other sources than
the Communications Act of 193U also must be boms by station licensees.
Thus a licensee must comply with the copyright laws or be subject to civil
suits for their infringement. He also is subject to libel and slander suits
growing out of material he may have broadcast* In addition to these matters
directly concerned with broadcasting he also is subject to many legal require-
ments of a more general nature.
